required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Next Generation INCEPTA Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD) and Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT-D) Field Following Study
clinical_study.official_title: Next Generation INCEPTA ICD and CRT-D Field Following Study: Respiratory Rate Trend Evaluation in Heart Failure (HF) Patients

brief_summary.textblock:
This study has 2 purposes:
The first purpose of the study is to test a new family of Boston Scientific Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators ("ICDs") and cardiac resynchronization therapy ICDs ("CRT-Ds") and show how well these new devices work in patients. This new family is called the INCEPTA ICD and the INCEPTA CRT-D.
The second purpose of the study is to collect data from a feature that monitors breathing. It is called the Respiratory Rate Trend (RRT). These data will help to better understand how changes in breathing relate to changes in clinical conditions.

detailed_description.textblock:
Study Purpose
Study purpose I:
To evaluate and document appropriate clinical performance of the INCEPTA (DR and VR) implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) system and the INCEPTA cardiac resynchronization therapy ICD (CRT-D) system and associated application software.
Study purpose II:
Demonstrate the clinical relevance of chronic ambulatory daily median Respiratory Rate Trend (RRT) in HF patients
Study Device
- INCEPTA (DR and VR) implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) system (Models F160, F161, F162, F163)
- INCEPTA cardiac resynchronization therapy ICD (CRT-D) system (Models P162, P163, P165)
Indication ICD / CRT-D Indication according to standard clinical practice
Study Objectives
The study has two primary objectives, linked to the respective study purposes:
For purpose I:
The objective is to collect data on the clinical performance of the INCEPTA ICD and CRT-D devices during standard clinical use at implant, pre-discharge and at a 1-month post-implant. Clinical performance included analysis of pacing thresholds, pacing impedance, sensing thresholds, number of successfully converted VT/VF episodes, induced episodes detection times, spontaneous episodes, wanded telemetry, adverse events (AEs) and product experiences.
For purpose II:
The objective is to show that daily median respiratory rate increases more in patients who experience an HF-event (Group 1) than in patients who do not experience an HF-event (Group 2).
This is a prospective, multi-centre, field following study.
Up to 35 study centers in the International geography will enrol 120 patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Product Experiences Reported by the Site for All Patients for Study Duration
primary_outcome.description: Product experiences reported may include the shock impedance noise display, problems encountered with the universal serial bus (USB), a program parameter mismatch, reverse mode switches, electrogram (EGM) noise without oversensing, lead connection issues, or customer device feedback.

primary_outcome.measure: Induced Ventricular Tachycardia / Ventricular Fibrillation (VT/VF) Episode Successful Conversion Rates at Implant
primary_outcome.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.

primary_outcome.measure: Induced VT/VF Episode Successful Conversion Rates at 1-month
primary_outcome.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.

primary_outcome.measure: Induced VT/VF Episode Successful Conversion Rates at 3-months
primary_outcome.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.

primary_outcome.measure: Induced Episode Detection Times at Implant
primary_outcome.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.

primary_outcome.measure: Induced Episode Detection Times at 1-month
primary_outcome.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.

primary_outcome.measure: Induced Episode Detection Times at 3 Months
primary_outcome.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.

primary_outcome.measure: Spontaneous Episode Conversion Success Rate at 3 Months
primary_outcome.description: Of the total patients that experienced a spontaneous episode, the % of patients with a spontaneous rhythm conversion that was successful was determined.

primary_outcome.measure: Wanded Telemetry Issues at Pre-discharge Follow-up
primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-Discharge visit occurred after implant but prior to 1 month follow-up visit
primary_outcome.description: The Investigators completed a questionnaire based on the performance of the wanded telemetry during device interrogations at pre-discharge follow-up. The number of problems reported were counted from the entire study cohort.

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the Daily Median Respiratory Rate Trend in Patients Who Experience a HF-event Compared to Patients Who do Not Experience a HF-event.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Results were captured from implant time window to the first event for patients with HFE, up to an average of 9 months
secondary_outcome.description: A comparison of the change in respiratory rate trend over time was made between patients who experienced a protocol-defined HF event (HFE) (Group1: Patients with a HFE) and patients who did not experience a protocol-defined heart failure event (Group 2: Patients without a HFE). Only patients with at least 3 valid daily respiratory rate values (60%) out of each 5-day window were evaluated. The objective was to show that daily median respiratory rate increases more in patients who experience a HFE (Group 1) than in patients who do not experience an HFE (Group 2). A comparison between patients who experience a HFE (Group 1) and patients who do not experience a HFE (Group 2). Two average daily median respiratory rates were done per patient: 60 to 56 days before an index time and 11 to 7 days before the same index time; the difference between these two averaged daily median respiratory rates was done. Index time=day of the first HFE (Group 1) and day of 6-month visit (Group 2).

arm_group.description: ICD and CRT-D indicated patients were included in the study. Overall patient population, CRT-D or ICD populations, and patients experiencing or not experiencing a protocol-defined heart failure event were included (dependent on outcomes measured).

study_pop.textblock: Patients should be selected from the investigator's general population and be indicated for an ICD or CRT-D implantation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are willing and capable of providing informed consent, undergoing a device implant, participating in all testing associated with this clinical study;
- Patients whose age is 18 or above, or of legal age to give informed consent specific to national law
- Patients indicated for an ICD according to normal clinical practice (for those patients receiving an INCEPTA ICD).
-As soon as 20 ICD patients are included in the study for purpose I, only NYHA Class III patients will be allowed in the study.
- New York Heart Association (NYHA) Class III patients indicated for a CRT-D according to normal clinical practice (for those patients receiving an INCEPTA CRT-D).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Women of childbearing potential who are or might be pregnant at the time of the study (method of assessment upon physician's discretion)
- Enrolled in any other concurrent study.
- Inability or refusal to comply with the follow-up schedule
- Patients that have received routinely scheduled intravenous inotropic therapy as part of their drug regimen within the past 90 days
- Patients prescribed to positive airway pressure therapy
- A life expectancy of less than 1 year, per physician discretion
- Patient in NYHA Class IV during the last 4 weeks

measure.description: Left Ventricular (LV) Sensed Amplitude results were reported at implant for CRT-D patients.
measure.population: The number of CRT-D patients with available data at implant

outcome.title: Evaluate the Daily Median Respiratory Rate Trend in Patients Who Experience a HF-event Compared to Patients Who do Not Experience a HF-event.
outcome.description: A comparison of the change in respiratory rate trend over time was made between patients who experienced a protocol-defined HF event (HFE) (Group1: Patients with a HFE) and patients who did not experience a protocol-defined heart failure event (Group 2: Patients without a HFE). Only patients with at least 3 valid daily respiratory rate values (60%) out of each 5-day window were evaluated. The objective was to show that daily median respiratory rate increases more in patients who experience a HFE (Group 1) than in patients who do not experience an HFE (Group 2). A comparison between patients who experience a HFE (Group 1) and patients who do not experience a HFE (Group 2). Two average daily median respiratory rates were done per patient: 60 to 56 days before an index time and 11 to 7 days before the same index time; the difference between these two averaged daily median respiratory rates was done. Index time=day of the first HFE (Group 1) and day of 6-month visit (Group 2).
outcome.time_frame: Results were captured from implant time window to the first event for patients with HFE, up to an average of 9 months
outcome.population: HF events were reported and adjudicated to classify patients into group 1 or 2. Group 1=17 HFEs in 13 patients. For patients with multiple HFEs,only the first with sufficient data was used. 8/13 with a HFE had data for the endpoint analysis.Group 2=95 patients with 9 month follow-up. 90/95 had data eligible for inclusion in the endpoint analysis.

group.title: Group1: Patients With a HFE
group.description: Patients who experienced a protocol-defined HF event

group.title: Group 2: Patients Without a HFE
group.description: Patients who did not experience a protocol-defined HFE

measure.title: Evaluate the Daily Median Respiratory Rate Trend in Patients Who Experience a HF-event Compared to Patients Who do Not Experience a HF-event.
measure.description: A comparison of the change in respiratory rate trend over time was made between patients who experienced a protocol-defined HF event (HFE) (Group1: Patients with a HFE) and patients who did not experience a protocol-defined heart failure event (Group 2: Patients without a HFE). Only patients with at least 3 valid daily respiratory rate values (60%) out of each 5-day window were evaluated. The objective was to show that daily median respiratory rate increases more in patients who experience a HFE (Group 1) than in patients who do not experience an HFE (Group 2). A comparison between patients who experience a HFE (Group 1) and patients who do not experience a HFE (Group 2). Two average daily median respiratory rates were done per patient: 60 to 56 days before an index time and 11 to 7 days before the same index time; the difference between these two averaged daily median respiratory rates was done. Index time=day of the first HFE (Group 1) and day of 6-month visit (Group 2).
measure.population: HF events were reported and adjudicated to classify patients into group 1 or 2. Group 1=17 HFEs in 13 patients. For patients with multiple HFEs,only the first with sufficient data was used. 8/13 with a HFE had data for the endpoint analysis.Group 2=95 patients with 9 month follow-up. 90/95 had data eligible for inclusion in the endpoint analysis.

outcome.title: Product Experiences Reported by the Site for All Patients for Study Duration
outcome.description: Product experiences reported may include the shock impedance noise display, problems encountered with the universal serial bus (USB), a program parameter mismatch, reverse mode switches, electrogram (EGM) noise without oversensing, lead connection issues, or customer device feedback.
outcome.population: All patients from overall study population were considered. Of the total population, the number of product experiences was reported.

group.title: INCEPTA CRT-D and ICD Patients (Overall Study Population)

measure.title: Product Experiences Reported by the Site for All Patients for Study Duration
measure.description: Product experiences reported may include the shock impedance noise display, problems encountered with the universal serial bus (USB), a program parameter mismatch, reverse mode switches, electrogram (EGM) noise without oversensing, lead connection issues, or customer device feedback.
measure.population: All patients from overall study population were considered. Of the total population, the number of product experiences was reported.

outcome.title: Induced Ventricular Tachycardia / Ventricular Fibrillation (VT/VF) Episode Successful Conversion Rates at Implant
outcome.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.
outcome.population: Of the 30 CRT-D and 22 ICD patients with induced episodes, the number with successful conversions was determined. The % of patients that had successful conversion was then reported.

measure.title: Induced Ventricular Tachycardia / Ventricular Fibrillation (VT/VF) Episode Successful Conversion Rates at Implant
measure.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.
measure.population: Of the 30 CRT-D and 22 ICD patients with induced episodes, the number with successful conversions was determined. The % of patients that had successful conversion was then reported.

outcome.title: Induced VT/VF Episode Successful Conversion Rates at 1-month
outcome.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.
outcome.population: Of all patients that experienced an induced VT/VF episode at 1-month, the number that had successful conversions was reported for both CRT-D and ICD patients.

measure.title: Induced VT/VF Episode Successful Conversion Rates at 1-month
measure.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.
measure.population: Of all patients that experienced an induced VT/VF episode at 1-month, the number that had successful conversions was reported for both CRT-D and ICD patients.

outcome.title: Induced VT/VF Episode Successful Conversion Rates at 3-months
outcome.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.
outcome.population: Of the 6 CRTD and 3 ICD patients that had induced VT/VF episodes at 3-month follow-up, the number of those that were converted successfully was reported in %

measure.title: Induced VT/VF Episode Successful Conversion Rates at 3-months
measure.description: The % of successful conversions after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. All episodes of induced VT/VF that resolved with successful conversion were counted from the total attempted conversions and reported as the % of successful conversions from those attempted.
measure.population: Of the 6 CRTD and 3 ICD patients that had induced VT/VF episodes at 3-month follow-up, the number of those that were converted successfully was reported in %

outcome.title: Induced Episode Detection Times at Implant
outcome.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.
outcome.population: Of the 30 CRT-D and 22 ICD patients with induced VT/VF episodes, the mean time required for conversion was reported for all available data

measure.title: Induced Episode Detection Times at Implant
measure.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.
measure.population: Of the 30 CRT-D and 22 ICD patients with induced VT/VF episodes, the mean time required for conversion was reported for all available data

outcome.title: Induced Episode Detection Times at 1-month
outcome.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.
outcome.population: Of the 1 CRT-D and 1 ICD patients that underwent induced VT/VF at 1month, the mean time for successful conversion was reported.

measure.title: Induced Episode Detection Times at 1-month
measure.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.
measure.population: Of the 1 CRT-D and 1 ICD patients that underwent induced VT/VF at 1month, the mean time for successful conversion was reported.

outcome.title: Induced Episode Detection Times at 3 Months
outcome.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.
outcome.population: Of the 6 CRT-D and 3 ICD patients with available data that had succesful conversion after induced VT/VF episodes, the mean time was determined at 3 months

measure.title: Induced Episode Detection Times at 3 Months
measure.description: The mean time it took to complete a successful conversion after inducing a VT/VF episode was analyzed for available data from CRT and ICD group patients. The time was recorded (in seconds) for the time duration that was required to successfully convert the patient after inducing VT/VF.
measure.population: Of the 6 CRT-D and 3 ICD patients with available data that had succesful conversion after induced VT/VF episodes, the mean time was determined at 3 months

outcome.title: Spontaneous Episode Conversion Success Rate at 3 Months
outcome.description: Of the total patients that experienced a spontaneous episode, the % of patients with a spontaneous rhythm conversion that was successful was determined.
outcome.population: Of the 13 CRT-D and 8 ICD patients that experienced a spontaneous episode, the successful conversions were reported.

measure.title: Spontaneous Episode Conversion Success Rate at 3 Months
measure.description: Of the total patients that experienced a spontaneous episode, the % of patients with a spontaneous rhythm conversion that was successful was determined.
measure.population: Of the 13 CRT-D and 8 ICD patients that experienced a spontaneous episode, the successful conversions were reported.

outcome.title: Wanded Telemetry Issues at Pre-discharge Follow-up
outcome.description: The Investigators completed a questionnaire based on the performance of the wanded telemetry during device interrogations at pre-discharge follow-up. The number of problems reported were counted from the entire study cohort.
outcome.time_frame: Pre-Discharge visit occurred after implant but prior to 1 month follow-up visit
outcome.population: 118 was the total number of questionnaires completed and available from the PI for analysis.

group.title: INCEPTA CRT-D and ICD (Overall Study Population)

measure.title: Wanded Telemetry Issues at Pre-discharge Follow-up
measure.description: The Investigators completed a questionnaire based on the performance of the wanded telemetry during device interrogations at pre-discharge follow-up. The number of problems reported were counted from the entire study cohort.
measure.population: 118 was the total number of questionnaires completed and available from the PI for analysis.

reported_events.time_frame: 9 months (with a window of plus/minus 1 month)

group.title: INCEPTA ICD and CRT-D
group.description: Patients implanted with Incepta ICD or CRT-D device

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Sponsor shall be provided with copy of all Trial-related manuscripts and reports for review and comment
